sn23.4:1.2.pli: Āyasmā rādho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ rādhaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn23.4:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Rādha went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
sn23.4:1.2.comm: The next seven discourses are the same as SN 22.106–12, but addressed to Rādha.

sn23.4:2.1.pli: “Pariññeyye ca, rādha, dhamme desessāmi pariññañca pariññātāviṃ puggalañca.
sn23.4:2.1.eng: “Rādha, I will teach you the things that should be completely understood, complete understanding, and the individual who has completely understood.

sn23.4:2.2.pli: Taṃ suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn23.4:2.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn23.4:2.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā rādho bhagavato paccassosi.

sn23.4:2.5.eng: “And what things should be completely understood?

sn23.4:2.6.pli: Rūpaṃ kho, rādha, pariññeyyo dhammo, vedanā pariññeyyo dhammo, saññā pariññeyyo dhammo, saṅkhārā pariññeyyo dhammo, viññāṇaṃ pariññeyyo dhammo.
sn23.4:2.6.eng: Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn23.4:2.7.eng: These are called the things that should be completely understood.

sn23.4:2.9.pli: Yo kho, rādha, rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo mohakkhayo—
sn23.4:2.9.eng: The ending of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn23.4:2.11.eng: And what is the individual who has completely understood?

sn23.4:2.12.eng: It should be said: a perfected one,

sn23.4:2.13.eng: the venerable of such and such name and clan.

sn23.4:2.14.eng: This is called the individual who has completely understood.”

sn23.46:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ rādhaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn23.46:1.2.eng: When Venerable Rādha was seated to one side, the Buddha said to him:

sn23.46:1.3.pli: “yo kho, rādha, nirodhadhammo; tatra te chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.
sn23.46:1.3.eng: “Rādha, you should give up any desire, any greed, any desire and greed for whatever is liable to cease.

sn23.46:1.4.eng: And what is liable to cease?

sn23.46:1.5.pli: Rūpaṃ kho, rādha, nirodhadhammo; tatra te chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.
sn23.46:1.5.eng: Form is liable to cease. You should give up any desire, any greed, any desire and greed for it.

sn23.46:1.9.pli: viññāṇaṃ nirodhadhammo; tatra te chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.
sn23.46:1.9.eng: Consciousness is liable to cease. You should give up any desire, any greed, any desire and greed for it.

sn23.46:1.10.pli: Yo kho, rādha, nirodhadhammo; tatra te chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo”ti.
sn23.46:1.10.eng: You should give up any desire, any greed, any desire and greed for whatever is liable to cease.”

sn23.46:2.7.eng: The Linked Discourses with Rādha are complete.

sn23.5:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ rādhaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn23.5:1.2.eng: When Venerable Rādha was seated to one side, the Buddha said to him:

sn23.5:1.3.eng: “Rādha, there are these five grasping aggregates.

sn23.5:1.5.eng: The grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn23.5:1.6.pli: Ye hi keci, rādha, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti;
sn23.5:1.6.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn23.5:1.7.pli: na me te, rādha, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca pana te āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn23.5:1.7.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn23.5:1.8.pli: Ye ca kho keci, rādha, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti;
sn23.5:1.8.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn23.5:1.9.pli: te kho me, rādha, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā, te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn23.5:1.9.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn23.6:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ rādhaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn23.6:1.2.eng: When Venerable Rādha was seated to one side, the Buddha said to him:

sn23.6:1.3.eng: “Rādha, there are these five grasping aggregates.

sn23.6:1.5.eng: The grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn23.6:1.6.pli: Ye hi keci, rādha, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti …pe…
sn23.6:1.6.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape … Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin …

sn23.6:1.7.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand … Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn23.7:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ rādhaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn23.7:1.2.eng: When Venerable Rādha was seated to one side, the Buddha said to him:

sn23.7:1.3.eng: “Rādha, there are these five grasping aggregates.

sn23.7:1.5.eng: The grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn23.7:1.6.pli: Yato kho, rādha, ariyasāvako imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti—
sn23.7:1.6.eng: When a noble disciple truly understands these five grasping aggregates’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape,

sn23.7:1.7.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, rādha, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyano”ti.
sn23.7:1.7.eng: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn23.8:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ rādhaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn23.8:1.2.eng: When Venerable Rādha was seated to one side, the Buddha said to him:

sn23.8:1.3.eng: “Rādha, there are these five grasping aggregates.

sn23.8:1.5.eng: The grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn23.8:1.6.pli: Yato kho, rādha, bhikkhu imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto hoti—
sn23.8:1.6.eng: A mendicant comes to be freed by not grasping after truly understanding these five grasping aggregates’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn23.8:1.7.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, rādha, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto”ti.
sn23.8:1.7.eng: Such a mendicant is called a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment.”

sn23.9:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ rādhaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn23.9:1.2.eng: When Venerable Rādha was seated to one side, the Buddha said to him:

sn23.9:1.3.pli: “rūpe kho, rādha, yo chando yo rāgo yā nandī yā taṇhā, taṃ pajahatha.
sn23.9:1.3.eng: “Rādha, you should give up any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for form.

sn23.9:1.4.pli: Evaṃ taṃ rūpaṃ pahīnaṃ bhavissati ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.
sn23.9:1.4.eng: Thus that form will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn23.9:1.5.pli: Vedanāya yo chando yo rāgo yā nandī yā taṇhā, taṃ pajahatha.
sn23.9:1.5.eng: You should give up any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for feeling …

sn23.9:1.6.pli: Evaṃ sā vedanā pahīnā bhavissati ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.

sn23.9:1.8.pli: saṅkhāresu yo chando yo rāgo yā nandī yā taṇhā, taṃ pajahatha.

sn23.9:1.9.pli: Evaṃ te saṅkhārā pahīnā bhavissanti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.

sn23.9:1.10.pli: Viññāṇe yo chando yo rāgo yā nandī yā taṇhā, taṃ pajahatha.

sn23.9:1.11.pli: Evaṃ taṃ viññāṇaṃ pahīnaṃ bhavissati …pe… anuppādadhamman”ti.
sn23.9:1.11.eng: Thus that consciousness will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.”

sn24.1:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane.
sn24.1:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove.

sn24.1:1.3.pli: “kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.1:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.1:1.4.pli: ‘na vātā vāyanti, na najjo sandanti, na gabbhiniyo vijāyanti, na candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā’”ti?
sn24.1:1.4.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’?”
sn24.1:1.4.comm: This doctrine of the illusory nature of change is found in Pali only in this chapter, and I have not been able to trace it elsewhere. We might call it the niccavāda, the “doctrine of permanence”. Nonetheless, the expression “standing firm like a pillar” is associated with eternalism generally (DN 1:1.33.11), and here links up with the seven uncreated substances (SN 24.8:1.3, MN 76:16.2, DN 2:26.2). This is attributed to Pakudha Kaccāyana, who is associated with the Ājivakas. Probably this is an expression of the Ājivaka belief that reality is fixed and change an illusion (Basham, History and Doctrines of the Ājīvikas, p. 236). | The form for “rivers” (najjo, irregular nominative plural of nadī) is unique to this passage.

sn24.1:2.1.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaññeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
sn24.1:2.1.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

sn24.1:2.2.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn24.1:2.2.eng: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn24.1:2.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn24.1:3.1.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.1:3.1.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn24.1:3.2.pli: ‘na vātā vāyanti, na najjo sandanti, na gabbhiniyo vijāyanti, na candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā’ti.
sn24.1:3.2.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’

sn24.1:3.6.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.1:3.6.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn24.1:3.7.pli: ‘na vātā vāyanti, na najjo sandanti, na gabbhiniyo vijāyanti, na candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā’ti.
sn24.1:3.7.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’

sn24.1:3.11.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.1:3.11.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn24.1:3.13.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.1:3.13.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:

sn24.1:3.14.pli: ‘na vātā vāyanti, na najjo sandanti, na gabbhiniyo vijāyanti, na candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā’”ti?
sn24.1:3.14.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”

sn24.1:4.4.comm: In the “six grounds for views” at MN 22:16.6, consciousness is absent, replaced by the “epistemic heptad” (see below). As a ground for views, “consciousness” means especially the states of expanded consciousness realized in deep meditation.

sn24.1:4.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.1:4.6.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn24.1:4.8.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.1:4.8.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:

sn24.1:4.9.pli: ‘na vātā vāyanti, na najjo sandanti, na gabbhiniyo vijāyanti, na candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā’”ti?
sn24.1:4.9.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”

sn24.1:4.11.pli: “Yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.1:4.11.eng: “That which is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by the mind: is that permanent or impermanent?”
sn24.1:4.11.comm: This set of seven appears at first glance to be somewhat arbitrary, as it combines four of the senses with meditation attainments. But it is not a description of sense experience. Rather, it describes how religious or spiritual beliefs come about, which is why smell, taste, and touch are omitted, and why it is introduced in this chapter. The truth, or what is believed to be the truth, is formulated from something “seen” (as a vision, or the sight of a pure being), “heard” (as teaching or scripture), “thought” (as philosophical reasoning), “known” (through understanding or meditation), or “attained, sought, and explored by the mind”, which specifically refer to meditative realization. Thus I propose referring to this set as the “epistemic heptad”. This is an extension of the more common epistemic tetrad, where meditative states are included under the “known” (MN 1:19.1).

sn24.1:4.13.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.1:4.13.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn24.1:4.15.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.1:4.15.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:

sn24.1:4.16.pli: ‘na vātā vāyanti, na najjo sandanti, na gabbhiniyo vijāyanti, na candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā’”ti?
sn24.1:4.16.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”

sn24.1:5.1.pli: “Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa imesu ca ṭhānesu kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhepissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhasamudayepissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhanirodhepissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāyapissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti—
sn24.1:5.1.eng: “When a noble disciple has given up doubt regarding these six grounds, and has given up doubt in suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,
sn24.1:5.1.comm: Six “grounds for views” are taught at MN 22:15.1: the first four aggregates taken as self, plus the epistemic heptad taken as self, plus the eternalist view. By analogy, the “six” here would be the first four aggregates, the epistemic heptad, and the specific view which varies per discourse. This, however, results in seven. We can resolve this by assuming that the Majjhima version is correct. “Consciousness” in this context should be replaced by the epistemic heptad, and only four aggregates are mentioned as such. Presumably the Saṁyutta redactors normalized the aggregates to the standard five.

sn24.1:5.2.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyano”ti.
sn24.1:5.2.eng: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn24.10:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.10:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.10:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.10:2.4.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.10:2.7.pli: “Yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?

sn24.10:2.9.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.10:2.9.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a view arise?”

sn24.10:3.1.pli: “Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa imesu ca ṭhānesu kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhepissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti …pe… dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāyapissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti—
sn24.10:3.1.eng: “When a noble disciple has given up doubt regarding these six grounds, and has given up doubt in suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,

sn24.10:3.2.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyano”ti.
sn24.10:3.2.eng: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn24.11:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.11:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.12:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.12:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.13:0.3.eng: The Soul and the Body Are Identical

sn24.13:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.13:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.13:1.3.eng: ‘The soul and the body are identical’?” …

sn24.14:0.3.eng: The soul is one thing, the body another

sn24.14:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.14:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.14:1.3.eng: ‘The soul is one thing, the body another’?” …
sn24.14:1.3.comm: This is a basic view of the Jains.

sn24.15:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.15:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.15:1.3.eng: ‘A realized one still exists after death’?” …

sn24.16:0.3.eng: A Realized One No Longer Exists

sn24.16:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.16:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.16:1.3.eng: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death’?” …

sn24.17:0.3.eng: A Realized One Both Still Exists and No Longer Exists

sn24.17:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.17:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.17:1.3.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti?
sn24.17:1.3.eng: ‘A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death’?” …

sn24.18:0.3.eng: A Realized One Neither Still Exists Nor No Longer Exists

sn24.18:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.18:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.18:1.3.pli: ‘neva hoti, na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti?
sn24.18:1.3.eng: ‘A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death’?”

sn24.18:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.18:2.1.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.18:2.1.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn24.18:2.2.pli: ‘neva hoti, na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti …pe….
sn24.18:2.2.eng: ‘A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death’ …

sn24.18:3.4.pli: vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.18:3.4.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:

sn24.18:3.5.pli: ‘neva hoti, na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti?
sn24.18:3.5.eng: ‘A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death’?”

sn24.18:3.7.pli: “Yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.18:3.7.eng: “That which is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by the mind: is that permanent or impermanent?”

sn24.18:3.9.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.18:3.9.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn24.18:3.11.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.18:3.11.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:

sn24.18:3.12.pli: ‘neva hoti, na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’”ti?
sn24.18:3.12.eng: ‘A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death’?”

sn24.18:4.1.pli: “Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa imesu ca ṭhānesu kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhepissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhasamudayepissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhanirodhepissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāyapissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti—
sn24.18:4.1.eng: “When a noble disciple has given up doubt regarding these six grounds, and has given up doubt in suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,

sn24.18:4.2.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyano”ti.
sn24.18:4.2.eng: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn24.18:5.2.pli: so attā no ca me siyā;

sn24.18:6.3.pli: Anantavā ca taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti,

sn24.18:7.3.pli: Neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti.
